metadata.title: W3Schools.com
metadata.Keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website
metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: JavaScript HTML DOM Navigation
With the HTML DOM, you can navigate the node tree using node relationships.
content.html: With the HTML DOM, you can navigate the node tree using node relationships.

content.text: DOM Nodes
According to the W3C HTML DOM standard, everything in an HTML document is a node:
content.html: According to the W3C HTML DOM standard, everything in an HTML document is a node:

content.text: With the HTML DOM, all nodes in the node tree can be accessed by JavaScript.
content.html: With the HTML DOM, all nodes in the node tree can be accessed by JavaScript.

content.text: New nodes can be created, and all nodes can be modified or deleted.
content.html: New nodes can be created, and all nodes can be modified or deleted.

content.text: Node Relationships
The nodes in the node tree have a hierarchical relationship to each other.
content.html: The nodes in the node tree have a hierarchical relationship to each other.

content.text: The terms parent, child, and sibling are used to describe the relationships.
content.html: The terms parent, child, and sibling are used to describe the relationships.

content.code_html:
<html>

  <head>
    <title>DOM Tutorial</title>
  </head>

  <body>
    <h1>DOM Lesson one</h1>
    <p>Hello world!</p>
  </body>

</html>

content.text: From the HTML above you can read:
content.html: From the HTML above you can read:

content.text: and:
content.html: and:

content.text: Navigating Between Nodes
You can use the following node properties to navigate between nodes with JavaScript:
content.html: You can use the following node properties to navigate between nodes with JavaScript:

content.text: Child Nodes and Node Values
A common error in DOM processing is to expect an element node to contain text.
content.html: A common error in DOM processing is to expect an element node to contain text.

content.code_html: <title id="demo">DOM Tutorial</title>

content.text: The element node <title> (in the example above) does not contain text.
content.html: The element node <title> (in the example above) does not contain text.

content.text: It contains a text node with the value "DOM Tutorial".
content.html: It contains a text node with the value "DOM Tutorial".

content.text: The value of the text node can be accessed by the node's innerHTML property:
content.html: The value of the text node can be accessed by the node's innerHTML property:

content.code_html: myTitle = document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML;

content.text: Accessing the innerHTML property is the same as accessing the nodeValue of the first child:
content.html: Accessing the innerHTML property is the same as accessing the nodeValue of the first child:

content.code_html: myTitle = document.getElementById("demo").firstChild.nodeValue;

content.text: Accessing the first child can also be done like this:
content.html: Accessing the first child can also be done like this:

content.code_html: myTitle = document.getElementById("demo").childNodes[0].nodeValue;

content.text:
All the (3) following examples retrieves the text of an

element and copies it into a

element:
content.html: All the (3) following examples retrieves the text of an <h1> element and copies it into a <p> element:

content.code_html:
<html>
<body>

<h1 id="id01">My First Page</h1>
<p id="id02"></p>

<script>
document.getElementById("id02").innerHTML = document.getElementById("id01").innerHTML;
</script>

</body>
</html>

<html>
<body>

<h1 id="id01">My First Page</h1>
<p id="id02"></p>

<script>
document.getElementById("id02").innerHTML = document.getElementById("id01").firstChild.nodeValue;
</script>

</body>
</html>

<html>
<body>

<h1 id="id01">My First Page</h1>
<p id="id02">Hello!</p>

<script>
document.getElementById("id02").innerHTML = document.getElementById("id01").childNodes[0].nodeValue;
</script>

</body>
</html>

content.text: InnerHTML
In this tutorial we use the innerHTML property to retrieve the content of an HTML element.
content.html: In this tutorial we use the innerHTML property to retrieve the content of an HTML element.

content.text: However, learning the other methods above is useful for understanding the tree structure and the navigation of the DOM.
content.html: However, learning the other methods above is useful for understanding the tree structure and the navigation of the DOM.

content.text: DOM Root Nodes
There are two special properties that allow access to the full document:
content.html: There are two special properties that allow access to the full document:

content.code_html:
<html>
<body>

<h2>JavaScript HTMLDOM</h2>
<p>Displaying document.body</p>

<p id="demo"></p>

<script>
document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = document.body.innerHTML;
</script>

</body>
</html>

<html>
<body>

<h2>JavaScript HTMLDOM</h2>
<p>Displaying document.documentElement</p>

<p id="demo"></p>

<script>
document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = document.documentElement.innerHTML;
</script>

</body>
</html>

content.text: The nodeName Property
The nodeName property specifies the name of a node.
content.html: The nodeName property specifies the name of a node.

content.code_html:
<h1 id="id01">My First Page</h1>
<p id="id02"></p>

<script>
document.getElementById("id02").innerHTML = document.getElementById("id01").nodeName;
</script>

content.text: Note: nodeName always contains the uppercase tag name of an HTML element.
content.html: Note: nodeName always contains the uppercase tag name of an HTML element.

content.text: The nodeValue Property
The nodeValue property specifies the value of a node.
content.html: The nodeValue property specifies the value of a node.

content.text: The nodeType Property
The nodeType property is read only. It returns the type of a node.
content.html: The nodeType property is read only. It returns the type of a node.

content.code_html:
<h1 id="id01">My First Page</h1>
<p id="id02"></p>

<script>
document.getElementById("id02").innerHTML = document.getElementById("id01").nodeType;
</script>

content.text: The most important nodeType properties are:
content.html: The most important nodeType properties are:

content.code_html:
Node Type Example
ELEMENT_NODE 1 <h1 class="heading">W3Schools</h1>
ATTRIBUTE_NODE 2  class = "heading" (deprecated)
TEXT_NODE 3 W3Schools
COMMENT_NODE 8 <!-- This is a comment -->
DOCUMENT_NODE 9 The HTML document itself (the parent of <html>)
DOCUMENT_TYPE_NODE 10 <!Doctype html>

content.text: Type 2 is deprecated in the HTML DOM (but works). It is not deprecated in the XML DOM.
content.html: Type 2 is deprecated in the HTML DOM (but works). It is not deprecated in the XML DOM.

content.text: Exercise ? What is this? Test your skills by answering a few questions about the topics of this page

Consider the following code:

Welcome

Read this.

Which one of the following statements is true?

<body>

  <p>Read this.</p>
</body>
